content.description:
A very difficult and rarely climbed line. Sit start on the right side of the rock below the arete with the right hand on a juicy pinch and the left hand on the sloping edge. Pull on making some difficult compression moves and climb up and rightward.

Stand start at v3 utilizing the deep slot.
content.location: Located on the Checkerboard Boulder, this line is on the same face on the far right.

content.description:
Begin on the right side of the face reaching up from the rock slab. Climb up and left via a long move to gain a crimp sidepull. Another hard move gains the good incut crimp for the right hand. From this position finish as for Checkerboard with the famous big "last" move. from here top out on good flakes!

An awesome climb avoiding the "no-fallzone" above the leftward rock slab on the original line. Many people have fallen and taken tumbles down the slab breaking bones! This line has a flat landing in comparison.
content.protection: Two or three crash pads and a few Spotters.
content.location: Start on the right side of the checkerboard looking patina face.

content.description:
Kind of not worth doing unless you've climbed every other variation.

Highball with a bad landing. -

Hope your crimp strength is up to date.

-

Stand start on top of the slab and reach to an incut crimp.

From here climb directly up using bad crimps and some high confidence.

Make some strenuous pulls until you can reach good patina finger jugs. Top out over a no fall zone and let out a sigh of relief.
content.protection:
Six pads and two spotters.

A stretcher or paramedics.
content.location: Same as for Checkerboard but climb direct.

content.description: A flaring crack that should probably be a lieback down low at the start.

Start at a prominent right-facing incut flake (not the jug rail just to the right) a bit left of center on the tall, slightly overhanging NW face of the 'Checkerboard Boulder'. Climb up and right to an exciting last move high off the deck. An excellent problem!
content.protection: Four or more pads would be ideal.  The sloping rock under the left part of this problem has leg-breaking potential.
content.location: This climb is located on the boulder farthest right in this area.  This boulder also happens to be the largest in the area, so finding it should not be difficult.
